title: Esophageal Perforation (Boerhaave's Syndrome)
diagnosis_topic: Transmural esophageal rupture following forceful emesis
setup_script: A 50-year-old man develops sudden severe chest pain and shortness of breath after repeated episodes of vomiting following a heavy meal. He has a history of alcoholism.

dynamic_flow.reply: BP 90/50 mmHg, HR 120 bpm, RR 28/min, Temp 38.2 C; patient appears toxic.
Severe chest pain radiating to the back, dyspnea and odynophagia after forceful retching; denies prior reflux.
Subcutaneous emphysema in the neck, mediastinal crepitus (Hamman's crunch) and tachypnea.
WBC 18 K/uL, elevated lactate; pleural fluid (if tapped) may show high amylase and food particles.
Pneumomediastinum and left pleural effusion; may show widened mediastinum.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident orders CT scan with IV and oral contrast
dynamic_flow.reply: Demonstrates contrast extravasation from distal esophagus into mediastinum with surrounding air and fluid.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident keeps patient NPO and initiates broad-spectrum IV antibiotics and antifungals
dynamic_flow.reply: Piperacillin-tazobactam and fluconazole started; NPO with NG decompression avoided to prevent contamination.
Patient taken emergently for operative repair with primary closure and drainage of mediastinum; endoscopic stent considered in contained leaks in stable patients.

dynamic_flow.trigger: If resident delays diagnosis and treatment
dynamic_flow.reply: Mediastinitis and sepsis progress rapidly leading to multi-organ failure.
Appropriate for contained cervical perforations without systemic toxicity; includes antibiotics and drainage.
NPO with jejunal feeding, serial imaging to assess healing and chest tube management.
Avoid excessive alcohol intake and seek care for severe vomiting in the future.

critical_decision_points: Recognition of esophageal perforation based on history of forceful vomiting and chest pain
Use of imaging (CT with contrast) to confirm diagnosis and locate perforation
Prompt initiation of NPO status, broad-spectrum antibiotics and surgical consultation
Selection between operative repair and non-operative management depending on containment and patient stability
Postoperative management including nutrition, drainage and prevention of mediastinitis
